title: Problem Statement
content: Erdős Problem #605 asks: Can n points on a sphere have superlinearly many pairs at the same distance? Specifically, does there exist f(n) → ∞ such that we can achieve f(n)·n repeated-distance pairs? The answer is YES, with f(n) = √(log n) working for all spheres of radius > 1.

title: Sphere Definition
content: A sphere of radius r in ℝ³ is the set of points at distance r from the origin. The 2-sphere S² is the surface (not the solid ball). Point configurations on spheres have different distance properties than planar configurations.

title: The √2 Sphere
content: The sphere of radius √2 is special: it can inscribe a cube with edge length 2, whose vertices lie on the sphere. This geometric property allows achieving the tight bound u(n) ≈ n^{4/3}, better than general spheres.

title: Sphere Configuration
content: A configuration is n distinct points on a sphere. We require injectivity (distinctness) and that all points lie on the sphere. The goal is to maximize repeated distances among the n(n-1)/2 pairs.

title: Counting Distance Pairs
content: For a configuration, we count how many pairs have exactly distance d. The maximum over all distances d gives the 'repeated distance count'. We want this to grow superlinearly in n.

title: The Function u_D(n)
content: u_D(n) = maximum number of pairs at a single distance, among all configurations of n points on a sphere of radius D. This is the central quantity. The question asks: does u_D(n) grow faster than O(n)?

title: Erdős Problem #605 Statement
content: The formal statement: Does there exist f : ℕ → ℝ with f(n) → ∞ such that u_D(n) ≥ f(n)·n for all large n? This asks whether repeated distances can grow superlinearly. The answer is YES.

title: Iterated Logarithm
content: log*(n) is the iterated logarithm: how many times you apply log until reaching ≤ 1. It grows incredibly slowly: log*(10^10^10) ≈ 4. Yet even this suffices for superlinear growth!

title: EHP Bound (1989)
content: Erdős-Hickerson-Pach proved u_D(n) ≫ n·log*(n) for any D > 1. This was the first superlinear bound, answering Problem #605 affirmatively. The iterated logarithm is tiny, but it DOES go to infinity.

title: Swanepoel-Valtr Bound (2004)
content: Swanepoel and Valtr improved to u_D(n) ≫ n·√(log n). This is much stronger than log*(n) - for n = 10^100, √(log n) ≈ 15 while log*(n) ≈ 5. The gap to the upper bound n^{4/3} remains open.

title: Upper Bound
content: For ALL radii D > 0, we have u_D(n) ≪ n^{4/3}. This comes from incidence geometry - points and circles in ℝ³ can't have too many incidences. The exponent 4/3 matches the √2 sphere lower bound.

title: √2 Sphere Tight Bound
content: For D = √2: u(n) ≈ n^{4/3} exactly. Both upper and lower bounds match! This uses cube vertices and related constructions. The √2 radius is special because cubes inscribe perfectly.

title: Main Theorem
content: Erdős #605 is solved: taking f(n) = √(log n), we have u_D(n) ≥ c·n·√(log n) for some c > 0 (Swanepoel-Valtr). Since √(log n) → ∞, the problem is answered affirmatively.

title: Great Circle Configuration
content: Placing n points evenly on a great circle gives a simple configuration. The distances form a multiset based on angles 2πk/n. This achieves linear repeated distances - good but not superlinear.

title: Asymptotic Notation
content: f ≫ g (asymptotically at least) means f(n) ≥ c·g(n) for some c > 0 and large n. f ≈ g (asymptotically equal) means both f ≫ g and g ≫ f. For √2 sphere: u(n) ≈ n^{4/3}.

title: Open Questions
content: Key open questions: (1) Is √(log n) optimal for general D > 1? (2) Can n^{4/3} be achieved for all D? (3) What happens for D = 1 exactly? The gap between √(log n) and n^{1/3} extra factor is mysterious.
